question: Which tendon connects the calf muscles to the heel bone?
short_explanation: The Achilles tendon attaches the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles to the calcaneus.
long_explanation: The Achilles tendon is the thickest and strongest tendon in the body, transmitting the force of calf muscle contraction to the heel for plantarflexion.
applied_example: Achilles tendonitis is common in runners and athletes; massage therapy can help reduce tension and inflammation.
text: Which tendon connects the calf muscles to the heel bone?

question: Which tendon stabilizes the lateral side of the ankle and foot?
short_explanation: The peroneal tendons run along the outside of the ankle and prevent excessive inversion.
long_explanation: These tendons originate from the peroneus longus and brevis muscles and help maintain lateral foot and ankle stability during gait and balance.
applied_example: Massage or taping techniques can help stabilize the peroneal tendons in athletes prone to ankle sprains.
text: Which tendon stabilizes the lateral side of the ankle and foot?

question: Which muscle tendon crosses in front of the ankle and inserts into the foot dorsum?
short_explanation: Tibialis anterior tendon controls dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot.
long_explanation: It plays a key role in lifting the foot during gait to prevent toe dragging. Dysfunction can cause 'foot drop.'
applied_example: Massage or nerve stimulation may assist with tibialis anterior weakness or gait retraining.
text: Which muscle tendon crosses in front of the ankle and inserts into the foot dorsum?

question: Which tendon is vulnerable to injury during explosive jumping or sprinting?
short_explanation: Explosive motion increases stress on the Achilles tendon, risking strain or rupture.
long_explanation: Sudden acceleration or deceleration can overload the Achilles tendon, especially if it's tight, weak, or inflamed.
applied_example: Massage therapy can be used in recovery and prevention, focusing on calf flexibility and load management.
text: Which tendon is vulnerable to injury during explosive jumping or sprinting?

question: Which tendon connects the quadriceps muscles to the tibial tuberosity?
short_explanation: The patellar tendon (or ligament) connects the patella to the tibia.
long_explanation: It continues the force from the quadriceps through the patella to extend the knee. It's essential in jumping and squatting.
applied_example: Massage may reduce tension in the quadriceps and patellar tendon in clients with knee pain or patellar tracking issues.
text: Which tendon connects the quadriceps muscles to the tibial tuberosity?

question: What is the main function of the hamstring tendons?
short_explanation: Hamstring tendons assist in knee flexion and hip extension.
long_explanation: These tendons originate at the ischial tuberosity and insert into the tibia and fibula, providing movement and posterior knee support.
applied_example: Massage techniques for tight hamstring tendons are common in athletic recovery and low back pain relief.
text: What is the main function of the hamstring tendons?
abcd: A. Knee flexion and hip extension
C. Hip abduction and external rotation

question: Which leg tendons are involved in eversion of the foot?
short_explanation: The peroneal tendons run along the lateral ankle and evert the foot.
long_explanation: These tendons provide dynamic lateral stability and are active during balance and gait to prevent inversion sprains.
applied_example: Eversion weakness is addressed with resistance exercises and lateral ankle mobilization.
text: Which leg tendons are involved in eversion of the foot?
abcd: A. Peroneus longus and brevis tendons
B. Tibialis posterior and flexor digitorum

question: Which tendon runs behind the medial malleolus in the tarsal tunnel?
short_explanation: Tibialis posterior passes through the tarsal tunnel behind the medial ankle.
long_explanation: This tendon provides arch support and assists in inversion. It is a key structure in tarsal tunnel syndrome.
applied_example: Manual therapy along the medial ankle can relieve symptoms of tarsal tunnel compression.
text: Which tendon runs behind the medial malleolus in the tarsal tunnel?

question: What structure do the tendons of the anterior leg compartment pass under at the ankle?
short_explanation: The extensor retinaculum holds tendons in place at the front of the ankle.
long_explanation: This fibrous band stabilizes extensor tendons during dorsiflexion, preventing bowstringing and ensuring smooth tendon glide.
applied_example: Massage over the retinaculum can reduce friction and improve movement efficiency in the anterior ankle.
text: What structure do the tendons of the anterior leg compartment pass under at the ankle?

question: Which combination of tendons forms the 'pes anserinus' on the medial knee?
answers: Rectus femoris, vastus medialis, and gastrocnemius
Biceps femoris, gluteus maximus, and soleus
Tibialis anterior, peroneus longus, and adductor longus
short_explanation: These three tendons insert together on the medial tibia and provide knee stability.
long_explanation: The pes anserinus is a conjoined tendon of sartorius, gracilis, and semitendinosus that supports medial knee function and resists valgus stress.
applied_example: Massage to this area can help with pes anserine bursitis or medial knee pain.
text: Which combination of tendons forms the 'pes anserinus' on the medial knee?
options: Rectus femoris, vastus medialis, and gastrocnemius
Biceps femoris, gluteus maximus, and soleus
Tibialis anterior, peroneus longus, and adductor longus
abcd: A. Sartorius, gracilis, and semitendinosus tendons
B. Rectus femoris, vastus medialis, and gastrocnemius
C. Biceps femoris, gluteus maximus, and soleus
D. Tibialis anterior, peroneus longus, and adductor longus
